sections.content: Everyone knows that ideas come from social media, but where does social media get its ideas?
The following is an entirely real screenshot. When the average person shares videos to their timeline, it looks something like...

content.text: Celebrating Indigenous Culture
Pride Parade 2021
Stop the spread of COVID-19
LET'S GET REAL ABOUT IMMIGRANTS >:(
How to save the rainforest

sections.content: Jesus what was that immigrant thing about? Maybe they had a bad day? Let's investigate the video.

From the thumbnail it appears, the video in question is one of those ice-cream videos where the Turkish guy keeps moving the ice cream cone every time the person goes to grab it. The person who is having the ice cream taken away? BEN SHAPIRO
Now or later they gotta apologize, because their timelines are public and eventually someone is going to see the post and take issue with it. Why is it like this?

Screenshot of right-wing content being shared on a timeline*
(leaving you the reader outraged!)
*In case you're wondering, these are loading correctly.

Sometimes people trust each other with their controversial content and sometimes this trust is broken. Let's check out this real screenshot of a chatbox with an example of the kind of humor that could cause trouble if it got out.

content.text: So there's 5 black guys walking in the park, they try to sit on a bench but it only fits 4 across. One of the black guys sits on his friend's lap. Which one's the gay guy?
None! Because we gots five homies, but we only gots four chairs!
I don't think this article is getting your point across. I'm still not really sure what it is.

sections.content: Screenshots can be damning but it's not fair to use them as evidence. Screenshots can be selectively cropped and edited. Standard practice should be to leak the whole transcript. I want to read the full convo from the beginning. Because when you scroll up you see things like...

content.text: Hey.
Hey,
I just realized this way of writing could be a modern way for reaching inaccessible parts of the personality.
Responding to messages from yourself seems to create some kind of link between parts of the brain that are usually separated.
We should do this later, doing it now is going to derail the article, plus I already announced this screenshot is supposed to explain the previous one.

Only the stupid readers don't know this isn't a real screenshot. Plus the original premise of the article isn't even any good. If you think about it for a few minutes there is plenty of public right-wing content. Way more than necessary to disprove your theory.
Yeah, I just felt that if I wrote about politics I would get views. We should be the characters the audience expected us to be in this dialogue we're performing.
Pretty much no one's going to get this far anyway, you opened way too political.
If no one's going to read it, why do you bother to fix your typos?
Because for the reader the words are already written, they couldn't see me make the change.
I saw the typo change so I'm confused. Are we the same person or different? Am I alone right now??
To the degree you remain insecure you'll never be alone. You're bringing society with you into everything you try to do.
That's lame because I don't really like our society.

sections.content: *that was weird, I meant to write about racism.
I'm not really sure what happened in that screenshot. Sometimes our brains are weirder than expected. Let's just move on.

sections.title: The algorithm's thoughts while chasing watchtime

content.title: Sexy Girl with Car
content.thought: Does he like the girl or the car?

content.title: Sexy Girl
content.thought: Hmmm. He didn't watch long. GPS data does indicate he may be gay.

content.title: Car
content.thought: Cars are acceptable in public but he did not watch long, maybe I'll try something gayer.

content.title: Gym Video with Boxing
content.thought: He liked that, let's do another.

content.title: Boxing
content.thought: How about some more boxing then?

content.title: Knockout
content.thought: A quick vid, but the best boxing has to offer.

content.title: MMA Knockout
content.thought: Let's get the legs involved too

content.title: Street Fight
content.thought: Screw all these rules let's show it raw and real

content.title: Street Fight in NY
content.thought: Funny yelling because it's New York. More watch time.

content.title: Street Fight in AFRICA — MACHETE
content.thought: Sorry! That was wayyy too extreme. My programmers told me not to do that again.

content.title: WHITE GUARD TACKLES BLACK THIEF
content.thought: Okay this is in a shopping center, no one gets maimed.

content.title: BLACK GUARD TACKLES WHITE THIEF
content.thought: Hmm, I guess just swapping 2 words in the title was uncreative. I'm sure there's nothing behind that.

content.title: White Bodybuilder
content.thought: He seems to really like this one. Let me take a risk then...

sections.title: Three in a row is too many

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Hey, we did it.
Yeah, that one turned out really well thanks for the help man.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: I don't know if I would say really well. It seems meta-racist and homophobic. Plus, I'm not even sure that's how phones work honestly.
I'm not even sure what part you're referring to. The GPS thing?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: That's part of it. I just feel that you would need to have some harmful stereotypes lurking in your mind to even think to write a bit like that. Like, who was that for? Did you have a target audience in mind?
Hey! I just wrote the titles and I was pretty careful about it. You did the “thoughts of the algorithm” captions.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Oh right, sorry I was being a Superego for a second. Even I lose track of the unconscious influences I put in your work.
But aren't you the one who puts them in there?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Yeah, but there are soooo many. It gets hard for me to remember even though I literally live in your memories.
Are you saying there are things in my work that are beyond my power or your power to describe and they may be self-evident to other people?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Yes, that's how it works. Your work is infinitely detailed, just most of it's not by you and only some of it's by me. But that doesn't mean you won't be judged by society for it.
... I can't even begin to process that.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: I'm disappointed in your opening paragraph.
We should just end this screenshot, it's gone too long.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Your opening paragraph implied social media doesn't have its own ideas.
I'm pretty sure everything on there is uploaded by humans, so it's the humans that have the ideas.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Is that how you really think a mind works?
I don't know how a mind works and it's dangerous to attempt to figure it out.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: You see the irony in that right? You are made up of cells that alone are nothing like you but when combined they are you. Your consciousness is independent of any individual cell.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: The cells of social media are the users, but the loss of a single user won't change social media very much. In fact, social media changes the users far more than the users change social media.
Are you saying social media has developed a sort of consciousness independent of the users?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: How can you be the mind and not know this?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: ...Jks, bro, I'm clearly the mind. You're just the part of the body that serves as the bridge to where I am.
Where are you supposed to be?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: I'm in the information world. No clunky matter and body to slow me down.
So what happens when one of your simulations is wrong?

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: We try to stay on top of it... but if a simulation is incorrect there is no way to actually know until we have a real experience to base our work on.
So my understanding of the world may be radically incorrect and neither me or the thing that's meant to be guiding me would know??

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Look, I'll be honest. Your understanding is probably running 17% at best.
That'll do, I've said more than I wanted to say.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: I think we made a good team.
I guess we'll find out about that. Worst comes to worst I'll just delete this article if it causes hassle.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: Have you considered that none of your heroes would do that? Instead, they would let the article stand as something that was written early in their career and grow beyond it.
Yeah, well I'm going to get a few other opinions before I post it.

content.speaker: Unconscious
content.text: I say let it ride. The audience isn't seeking perfection.
If that's true I might have a chance. But I'm really not sure that this is what the audience wants.

sections.content: Where does social media get its ideas from? It gets them from the experiences of people. If we're lucky, figuring out its nature may provide insight into something beyond ourselves.
